stem: A 58-year-old client received a transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells 7 days ago. The client returns to the clinic reporting fatigue and yellowing of the eyes. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Rule out late transfusion complications.
Background: History of anemia and multiple previous transfusions. Transfused 1 week ago during knee surgery.
Assessment: Client has mild scleral icterus and dark-colored urine. Hematocrit has dropped since discharge.
Recommendation: Direct Antiglobulin Test (DAT) and Bilirubin screen.

actionOptions.text: Notify the Blood Bank to screen for newly developed antibodies.
Administer IV fluids to maintain renal perfusion as prescribed.
Perform a STAT needle decompression of the chest.
Apply cooling blankets and withhold all lab work.

parameterOptions.text: Serum Indirect Bilirubin and Haptoglobin levels
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing a Delayed Hemolytic Transfusion Reaction (DHTR) (c2), which typically occurs 3–14 days after transfusion. It is caused by an amnestic (memory) response to a previously encountered Minor Blood Group antibody. Signs include a falling Hgb, rising indirect bilirubin (jaundice), and a positive Coombs test (DAT). The nurse must notify the Blood Bank (a1) so future units can be cross-matched for the new antibody and support the kidneys with fluids (a2) to clear the hemoglobin breakdown products. Tracking Hgb (p1) and Bilirubin (p2) is essential.
clinicalPearls: Acute Hemolytic = ABO mismatch. Delayed Hemolytic = Minor antibody mismatch (Rh, Kidd, Kell).
Jaundice and dark urine occur because the body is breaking down red cells too fast for the liver to process.
DHTR is often missed because the symptoms appear after the patient has gone home.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking this is a new bleed because the Hgb dropped.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Look at the Bilirubin and Urine! If the Hgb drops AND the Bilirubin rises/Urine is dark, it's hemolysis, not just an active bleed.

mnemonic.title: Delayed = Days
mnemonic.expansion: D-Days later. E-Eyes yellow (Jaundice). L-Lower Hgb. A-Antibody developed.
